citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The licensee failed to have frequent and direct communication with their attending veterinarian regarding the emaciated
body condition of one female Shih Tzu "Dazzle" MC#933000320329393. The dam gave birth to 8 puppies on 11-March-
2024 and 7 were stillborn. The licensee states she had a hard labor and is still recovering. They are providing a "puppy
mush" consisting of Nutri-cal, water and puppy food free choice. The dam had received a bowl of this mush the morning
of inspection and the bowl was empty. The licensee provided an additional bowl of mush and the dog smelled it and
walked away. The dam has visible ribs, vertebrae and hip bones with little to no fat or muscle covering. The hair coat is
thin and patchy as well with little to no hair on her tail. The licensee does not have a treatment plan approved by the
attending veterinarian for underweight dogs and has not contacted the attending veterinarian regarding this dog. An
emaciated or underweight body condition could indicate an underlying health issue and if left untreated could result in the
pain, distress, additional systemic problems or death of the animal.
The licensee must have frequent and direct communication with the attending veterinarian so that timely and accurate
information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being can be evaluated by the attending veterinarian. This
dog must be evaluated by a licensed veterinarian for an accurate diagnosis and to develop an effective treatment plan in
writing. This treatment plan must be made available for APHIS inspection.
To be corrected by: End of Business 10-April-2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(3)  Direct
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The licensee failed to have frequent and direct communication with their attending veterinarian regarding the emaciated 
body condition of one female Shih Tzu "Dazzle" MC#933000320329393. The dam gave birth to 8 puppies on 11-March-
2024 and 7 were stillborn. The licensee states she had a hard labor and is still recovering. They are providing a "puppy 
mush" consisting of Nutri-cal, water and puppy food free choice. The dam had received a bowl of this mush the morning 
of inspection and the bowl was empty. The licensee provided an additional bowl of mush and the dog smelled it and 
walked away. The dam has visible ribs, vertebrae and hip bones with little to no fat or muscle covering. The hair coat is 
thin and patchy as well with little to no hair on her tail. The licensee does not have a treatment plan approved by the 
attending veterinarian for underweight dogs and has not contacted the attending veterinarian regarding this dog. An 
emaciated or underweight body condition could indicate an underlying health issue and if left untreated could result in the 
pain, distress, additional systemic problems or death of the animal. 
The licensee must have frequent and direct communication with the attending veterinarian so that timely and accurate 
information on problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being can be evaluated by the attending veterinarian. This 
dog must be evaluated by a licensed veterinarian for an accurate diagnosis and to develop an effective treatment plan in 
writing. This treatment plan must be made available for APHIS inspection. 
To be corrected by: End of Business 10-April-2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
